awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Next Generation of STEM Teacher Preparation in Washington State
awd_abstract_narration:
The Next Generation of STEM Teacher Preparation project is led by five institutions of higher education in Washington State.  This collaborative effort will engage institutions involved in the preparation of teachers of STEM disciplines, Washington State's Office of the Superintendent of Public Instruction, P-12 educators, and other key stakeholders from business, government, and non-governmental organizations (NGOs), in bringing about statewide sustainable change in the preparation of STEM teachers at all levels.  The project moves away from isolated, single institutional program improvement efforts, to colleges and universities in Washington State working collaboratively to improve STEM teacher preparation in partnership with two-year colleges, P-12 schools, community groups, and businesses. The project will result in the production of more, highly qualified, P-12 science and mathematics teachers, including a new cadre of teachers prepared to teach computer science and engineering. In addition, the project seeks to increase the diversity of the STEM teacher workforce by actively recruiting and incentivizing underrepresented students from STEM majors at 2- and 4-year colleges to become P-12 middle and high school STEM teachers.  Financial support for this project comes from NSF's Improving Undergraduate Education program and the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program.

The project's primary goals are: 
1.	To improve STEM teacher preparation programs in Washington State (impacting greater than 90% of the state's future STEM teacher graduates,
2.	Increase recruitment of qualified and diverse STEM students into teaching, and
3.	Create an adaptive, research-based model for improving STEM teacher preparation through collaboration. 
To achieve these goals, the project will: (a) create a common vision for STEM teacher preparation in Washington State, (b) share, develop, adapt, implement, and evaluate resources and models to achieve this vision, and (c) build and assess a model of continuous, collaborative program improvement. The critical components of teacher preparation this project will address include:  improving pre-service teachers' clinical practice and new teachers' induction experiences, improving the disciplinary and STEM pedagogical content knowledge of pre-service teachers, and integrating computer science, engineering, and sustainability into teacher preparation. Cross-institutional Working Groups dedicated to improving each component will research, create, and produce a set of materials and professional development workshops. Regional Teams of faculty and administrators from institutions of higher education, P-12 educators, and representatives from STEM businesses, NGOs, and government agencies, will in turn adapt these materials and professional development experiences to support and sustain STEM teacher preparation program improvements at their institutions. Three capacity-building components: organizational change, increasing the diversity of the STEM teaching workforce, and collaboration building, will underlie the efforts of every Working Group and Regional Team.

por.por_cntn:
The Next Generation of STEM Teacher Preparation in Washington State project was a collaboration amongst faculty from colleges of Education and colleges of Arts & Sciences from eight major teacher preparation universities and numerous two- and four-year public and private institutions of higher education (IHEs) across Washington State. Additionally, partnerships were developed across IHEs and governmental and non-governmental organizations and K-12 teachers, administrators, and districts. 

The goals of the Next Generation of STEM Teacher Preparation in Washington State (NextGen-WA) project were to:

1.  Improve STEM teacher preparation programs in Washington State (impacting greater than 90% of Washington?s future STEM teacher graduates) by:

a.     aligning Washington State's science and math teacher preparation programs to support the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) and Common Core State Standards in mathematics,

b.     implementing new courses and programs to support computational thinking and computer science teaching,

c.     developing stronger ties between science and math teacher preparation programs within and across institutions,

d.     improving understanding of what it means to prepare secondary science and math teachers to be STEM teachers and elementary educators to be teachers of STEM.

2.  Increase recruitment of qualified and diverse STEM students into teaching by better articulating pathways, incentives, and supports for diverse STEM students to become teachers.

3.  Create and test an adaptive, research-based model for improving STEM teacher preparation through statewide collaboration.

To achieve the above goals, working groups composed of IHE faculty and partners from other organizations were created. Goal 1 was addressed by six working groups with the following foci: Pedagogical Content Knowledge, Clinical Practice, Education for Sustainability, Computer Science Integration, Engineering Integration, and M(ath) in STEM. Progress toward Goal 2 was led by a Diversity working group whose members provided professional learning and support for all institutional teams. Goal 3, the development of a collaborative model, involved the leadership team in creating and documenting the structures, processes, and activities that supported the collaborative work.

The NextGen-WA project impacted STEM teacher preparation at WSU and statewide. At both institutional and statewide levels, the project helped us develop more nuanced and shared understandings about what high quality, effective STEM teacher preparation includes and ways to engage and support students historically underrepresented in STEM teaching and learning. Prior to this project, STEM teacher preparation programs in Washington State operated independently from one another and varied widely with respect to curricular goals and learning experiences. As a result of this project, faculty from IHEs across the state continue to work together to develop approaches for student recruitment and retainment in STEM teacher preparation, high quality courses, and strategies and processes that support needed changes at the organization and policy levels. We developed and will soon publish a complete description of this adaptive model for collaborative improvement of STEM teacher preparation, including the resources, frameworks, processes, and challenges; this may be useful to others interested in collaborative improvement. Early resources and processes can be found here: https://serc.carleton.edu/nextgen_wa/index.html.

Within Washington State University, participation in NextGen-WA resulted in the collaborative development and implementation of curricula and workshops for university faculty from multiple WSU colleges and campuses, preservice and inservice teachers, and graduate students in: a) computational thinking and computer science teaching; b) ambitious mathematics and science teaching practices across K-16; c) integrated STEM; and d) education for sustainability. Undergraduate and graduate courses in education, computer science, biology, and environmental science were developed or re-designed based on research done through the project. Project-developed resources that may support others in evaluating and redesigning their own STEM teacher preparation programs include curricular units and lessons, as well as landscape analyses and frameworks related to clinical practice, education for sustainability, engineering, and mathematics in teacher preparation. These and other resources we drew upon or developed during this statewide, collaborative model can be found here: Innovations in STEM Teacher Preparation: A searchable Toolkit. https://serc.carleton.edu/stemteacherprep/index.html.

Additionally, we held a conference on Wicked Problems in STEM Teacher Preparation in June, 2021, to engage STEM educators from across the U.S. in collaborative work to improve STEM teacher preparation. Post-conference surveys indicated the conference helped participants clarify the complex system and multiple variables impacting three significant problems in STEM education: 1) enhancing equity, diversity, and inclusion in K?12 STEM Teacher Preparation; 2) preparing and supporting all elementary teachers to be teachers of STEM; and 3) creating interdisciplinary and culturally sustaining secondary STEM teacher preparation programs. Information about this conference can be found here: https://nextgenstemconference.org/
